What money have we available for such a purpose? There is a very old song that used to be sung by Britishers -

quote.para: We've got the ships, we've got the men,
We've got the money too.

speech.para: But the Commonwealth has neither the men nor the money for this undertaking. I dare say that the honorable member for Maranoa will recognise that we have not enough men to carry on our shearing operations, and to perform other services in connexion with our rural occupations.

talk.start.para: - We were able to send some to South Africa.

- That is so. We all were delighted with the reception given by the people of Great Britain to our representatives at the Imperial Conference. The outstanding feature of that Conference was the loyalty evidenced by General Botha to the British flag, and even if the gathering had no other result, the great sentiment of loyalty which permeated it would fully justify it. There are many other matters with which I should like to deal, but I take it that other opportunities for their discussion must necessarily occur. I do not wish at this late hour to inflict a lengthy speech upon the House. I thank honorable members for their kindly attention to the few words I have said, and sincerely hope that however we may differ on political questions, that camaraderie which is one of the best features of a Parliament will be evidenced, not only by myself and my confreres on this side, but by honorable members generally.
- I should like to move the adjournment of the debate.

. - I do not know how many honorable members are anxious to take part in the debate, but I trust that, if possible, it will be closed to-morrow. We have no desire to unduly curtail the discussion of the motion, but I would remind the House that it has been before us for some days, and that it should be brought to an early close. I am prepared to agree, as I did last night, to the adjournment of the debate at a comparatively early hour, since we are still early in the session, but I trust that we shall bring it to a close, if not to-morrow, at the latest on Friday. If honorable members conclude the debate to-morrow the Government will be ready to agree to an adjournment of the House until" Tuesday next.

speech.para: Debate (on motion by Mr. Bruce Smith) adjourned.

debate.para: Motion (by Sir William Lyne) agreed to -
That leave be given to bring in a Bill for an Act relating to Quarantine.
Bill presented, and read a first time.

talk.start.para: asked the Postmaster-General, upon notice -

item.para: Has the bond of£25,000 in connexion with the cancelled mail contract with Sir James Laing and Sons yet been converted into cash ?
If not, what is the present position of affairs in relation to the matter?

Is it true, as stated in the press, that Messrs. Barclay and Co. repudiate any liability under the bond on the ground that it was given in respect of a contract other than the one finally agreed upon?
Will he lay upon the Table of the House all the papers relating to the matter?

talk.start.para: - The answers to the honorable member's questions are as follow : -

item.para: The guarantee for£25,000 referred to has not been converted into cash, so far as I am aware.
The representative of the Commonwealth in London was instructed to' demand payment of the guarantee at the time the contract was cancelled.
I have not heard that Barclay and Co. repudiate any liability under the guarantee.

talk.start.para: asked the Postmaster-General, upon notice -

item.para: Was the agreement with Sir James Laing and Sons, of 7th July, 1906, for carriage of mails, the approval of which the Honorable the Postmaster-General moved on 18th July, 1906, subject to the approval of this House?

Was it approved of as signed? If not, was the bank guarantee, which the Honorable the Postmaster-General in his speech said he had, altered or a new one obtained, so that the guarantee might apply to the agreement as altered?

item.para: Yes.

No. The guarantee referred to by me was handed back, and a new one obtained in London on the 13th December, 1906, after copies of the contract, as approved by Parliament and agreed to bv the contractors through their agents, had reached London.

talk.start.para: asked the Prime Minister, upon notice -

item.para: Did the Commonwealth Government submit to the Government of New South Wales a proposal that officers of the Postal Department should distribute weekly allowance to old-age pensioners ?
What sum did the Commonwealth Government require from New South Wales in payment for the proposed service?
Can he say whether it is correct that the Government of New South Wales pays a private banking institution £10,000 per year for making the necessary distributions to old-age pensioners in that State?
What reasons, if any, were given by the New South Wales Government for rejecting the offer of the Federal Government, and for employing a private corporation to distribute the Old-age Pension Fund ?

talk.start.para: - The answers to the honorable member's questions are as follow : -

item.para: In response to an inquiry made, in 1904, by the Premier of New South Wales, the Commonwealth Government intimated that it would be prepared to undertake the payment of old-age pensions at post offices and country centres.
A commission at the rate of 12s. 6d. per centum, equal to a total sum of about£3,375 per annum.

It is not known what the total payment by the Government of New South Wales to the private banking institution amounts to, but for the country centres alone it is understood that the payment at £2 per centum amounts to about £10,800per annum.

No special reasons have been given by the New South Wales Government for not accepting the offer of the Commonwealth Government. A communication was, however, received from the Premier of New South Wales, stating he bad been informed that in Victoria the payment of old age pensions was carried out by postmasters without charge to the State, and asking that in the event of such information being correct, a similar concession be extended to the New South Wales Government. In reply, the Premier of New South Wales was informed that the work could not be done without charge, and that a charge at the same rate as was suggested for his State was being made on the Victorian Government.
